Article.ArticleTitle: The prenatal and postnatal effects of air pollution on asthma in children with atopic dermatitis.

AbstractText: Air pollution is strongly associated with asthma, but has not been determined to induce new-onset asthma development in children with atopic dermatitis (AD).
To assess whether prenatal/postnatal exposure to air pollutants triggers new-onset asthma development in children with AD.

Data of patients <age 18 years diagnosed with eczema or AD between 2009 and 2019 were extracted from the multicenter Kaohsiung Medical University Hospital Research Database. Patients diagnosed with new-onset asthma were in the asthma group and patients without asthma history were in the non-asthma group.

The monthly average concentration of air pollutants for 1, 3, and 5 years before the index date, and 3, 6, and 9 months prenatally were analyzed and further stratified by age, immunoglobulin (Ig) E, and the percentage of eosinophil and eosinophil cationic protein (ECP).

Postnatal exposure to airborne particulate matter (PM<sub>2.5</sub> , PM<sub>10</sub> ), sulfur dioxide (SO<sub>2</sub> ), ozone (O<sub>3</sub> ), carbon monoxide (CO), nitric oxide (NO), nitric dioxide (NO<sub>2</sub> ), and NO<sub>x</sub> , and prenatal exposure to PM<sub>2.5</sub> , PM<sub>10</sub> , SO<sub>2</sub> , NO, and NO<sub>x</sub> were significantly higher in the asthma group than in the non-asthma group. Patients having IgE above 100 IU/ml and ECP less than 24 ng/ml were significantly influenced by postnatal exposure to PM<sub>2.5</sub> and PM<sub>10</sub> , especially CO, to develop asthma, and those having an eosinophil count >3% were significantly influenced by prenatal exposure to PM<sub>2.5</sub> , especially SO<sub>2</sub> , NO, and NO<sub>2</sub> .
Prenatal and postnatal exposure to air pollution have an association with asthma development in AD patients.
